entry.title: 康卡斯特回应呼吁停止其误导性的“10G 网络”声明：✊🍆
entry.content:
乔恩·布罗德金 (Jon Brodkin)，Ars Technica：

一个广告行业组织敦促康卡斯特停止其“10G”广告或对其进行修改，以表明 10G 是一项“理想的”技术，而不是该公司目前在其有线网络上实际提供的技术。国家广告部门 (NAD) 是 BBB 国家计划运营的广告行业自律体系的一部分，在 T-Mobile 提出质疑后做出了对康卡斯特不利的裁决。

在周四宣布的决定中，NAD 建议康卡斯特“停止其‘10G’声明”或“修改其广告，以 (a) 明确表示其正在实施将使其能够实现‘10G’的改进，并且它是有抱负的或(b) 按照本决定，以不虚假或误导性的方式使用“10G”。”

康卡斯特计划对这一决定提出上诉，因此不会立即对营销做出任何改变。如果康卡斯特败诉并同意改变其做法，影响的将不仅仅是一些广告，因为康卡斯特现在将其整个宽带网络称为“10G”。

这真是太搞笑了。编造“10G”这个名字是康卡斯特对经典“去他妈的一切，我们要做五个刀片”方法的诠释。

entry.title: '暴力'
entry.content:
约瑟夫·西蒙森 (Joseph Simonson) 在《华盛顿自由灯塔》中，“纽约大学法学院学生称同学因支持哈马斯的言论而失去工作机会是‘暴力’”：

纽约大学法学院的学生聚集在一名因捍卫哈马斯而失去白鞋律师事务所职位的学生身边，称该公司撤销其聘用的决定构成了“暴力”。

纽约大学非二元学生瑞娜·沃克曼 (Ryna Workman) 发表声明，声称“以色列对造成 1,300 多人死亡（其中至少有 30 名美国人）的恐怖袭击负有全部责任”，之后总部位于芝加哥的 Winston & Strawn 撤回了对她的聘用。根据华盛顿自由灯塔获得的一封支持信，该公司的决定只是沃克曼自发表反以色列声明以来经历的“系统性、集中暴力”的一个例子。

这封信的签署者包括黑人联盟法律学生协会和有色人种妇女集体，指责纽约大学“参与以色列政府的虐待行为”，并谴责“更广泛的纽约大学管理部门没有保护作为学生和重要人物的瑞娜”。我们社区的一员。”

言语是有意义的。多年来，极左派一直在歪曲暴力的定义，颠覆了古老的格言：棍棒和石头可以打断你的骨头，但言语永远不会伤害你。当然，言语会伤人——很深。但这是一种不同于暴力造成的痛苦和屠杀的伤害。如果加沙和以色列之间唯一的交流是言语，无论这些言语有多么可恨，我们的处境将会好得多。

这些学生应该被大学开除，而不是安抚。在这种背景下滥用暴力——一场恐怖袭击造成 1,300 名无辜以色列人死亡， 数千人受伤，并在由此引发的仍在展开的战争中杀死了数千名巴勒斯坦人——是极其无礼的。许多死者的身份无法辨认。他们刚刚被炸得四分五裂。这就是暴力。每个人都知道这个词的真正含义——“使用武力来伤害、虐待、破坏或破坏”。这些左翼疯子愚蠢地假装这个词有其他含义，其原因甚至可能让奥威尔这位以政治之名识别语言衰落的大师感到惊讶。如有疑问，请不要相信那些滥用语言、混淆视听、诉诸委婉语和重新定义词语的人。

entry.summary: 重点应该是让“*我应该购买哪款 iPad？*”这个问题尽可能容易回答。
entry.content:
丹·莫伦 (Dan Moren) 在《六色》中写道：

这款铅笔显然是为与第十代 iPad 一起使用而设计的：虽然它通过磁性吸附在 iPad 的长边上进行存储，但它仍然通过物理端口充电。与旧款 Lightning 型号不同，旧款 Lightning 型号有一个可拆卸（且容易丢失）的盖子，隐藏着充电和配对连接器，新款 Apple Pencil 具有创新的滑动设计，露出一个 USB-C 端口，您可以在其中插入电缆（当然， ，不包括在内）。它的设计在其他方面与第二代 Pencil 非常相似。

这款铅笔售价 79 美元，比第一代型号 99 美元和第二代型号 129 美元便宜。但那是因为它不具备这两款产品的所有功能：它缺少之前两款产品的压力敏感度，以及第二代的双击控制、无线配对和充电以及免费雕刻功能。 。不过，新款 Pencil确实支持 M2 iPad Pro 型号上的“悬停”功能。

一方面，这款新铅笔完全有意义。闪电很快就消失了，这个新的滑块似乎比旧的盖子更好的设计。但另一方面，现在 Apple Pencil 共有三种型号，每种型号都有不同的功能，并且由不同的 iPad 支持，这一事实说明了 iPad 产品阵容是多么复杂。

Jason Snell 在他自己的观点中指出了这一点：

尽管如此，看到过去几年 iPad 产品线的恶作剧，我们还是很难不感觉到事情有点混乱。这款新 Pencil 应该是去年与第 10 代 iPad 一起发售的。新款 iPad 具有高端机型所没有的功能。 iPad Air 和 iPad Pro 之间的差异化不够。 （抛开旧型号不谈，感觉 iPad 太多了，不是吗？）

然而，我们有可能正在见证一次重置。今年还没有发布任何一款新 iPad，而且考虑到周二 Apple Pencil 的发布，感觉肯定不会再发布。也许 2024 年会给我们带来新一波的 iPad，最终让我们的产品线变得更有意义。但不要抱太大希望：苹果可能仍会继续销售一些旧型号。这就是今天的苹果所做的。

我突然想到，我希望 Apple 明年在 iPad 上提供什么：

  • 将旧的第 9 代 iPad 从产品阵容中剔除。那台 iPad 太旧了，仍然有一个主页按钮。
  • 第 10 代 iPad 的价格降低 100 美元。 （或许可以让它从 A14 芯片升级到 A15 芯片？但希望降价和更新芯片可能只是一厢情愿。）
  • 更新 iPad Air（和 Mini？）型号，使其更像今天的 iPad Pro，使用 Face ID 而不是 Touch ID。 1
  • iPad Pro 的重大改版，自 2018 年以来，外形尺寸没有发生重大变化。在 iPad Pro 中加入更多专业元素，就像苹果对 iPhone 15 Pro 机型所做的那样。
  • 更新妙控键盘，最好继续支持 iPad Air 和 11 英寸 iPad Pro。妙控键盘是一个好主意，我认为也是一个很受欢迎的主意。但它应该更好——更薄、更轻、更耐用。 （白色的尤其容易老化。在野外、咖啡馆和机场时请留意它们 - 它们通常看起来很脏。与MacBook进行比较和对比，即使经过多年的日常使用，MacBook 也通常看起来很棒。）报道称，对妙控键盘的此类修订正在进行中。

这将澄清 iPad 的三个等级：好（普通 iPad，第 10 代）、更好（iPad Air - 大多数人的最佳选择）和最佳（iPad Pro，具有先进的新特性和功能）。重点应该是提出这样一个问题：“我应该购买哪款 iPad？ ” 尽可能简单地回答。我认为苹果已经让 iPhone、MacBook 和手表以及 AirPods 等外围设备很容易回答这个问题。 2现在为 iPad 执行此操作。

  1. 感觉这是一个非常安全的假设，这里的问题是成本：Face ID 组件很昂贵，因此非 Pro iPad 配备了 Touch ID 按钮。我确信有很多快乐的 iPad Air 用户不会被 Touch ID 所困扰。但如果你曾经使用过配备 Face ID 的 iPad Pro，那么在使用 iPad Air 时就不可能不感到烦恼。 Face ID 不仅是一种与 Touch ID 不同的生物身份验证形式，而且是一种明显更优越的生物身份验证方式。当我回顾它们时，它一直是我关注的焦点。来自我一年前对当前 iPad Air 的评论：

    对我来说，仅 Face ID 就值 150 美元。我经常（甚至大部分时间）在妙控键盘上使用 iPad。这是我的厨房电脑。我发现当 iPad Air 位于妙控键盘中时，在电源按钮上使用 Touch ID 有点尴尬。但妙控键盘是一款售价 300 美元的外设。它不是一个利基产品，但它肯定不适合所有人。 iPad 本质上是手持式平板电脑，而手持式 iPad Air 的 Touch ID 与 Face ID 的区别要小得多。不过，我仍然更喜欢 Face ID。 iPad Air 上的 Touch ID 让解锁变得轻松简单。 iPad Pro 上的 Face ID 让人感觉它根本就没有被锁定。

    iPhone 上除了 SE 之外，现在所有销售的型号都配备了 Face ID。 iPad 也应该如此：除了以价格为中心的入门机型之外，每一款 iPad 都应该如此。与 MacBook 相比，这个功能太好了，也是 iPad 的一个关键优势。 ↩︎︎

  2. 一款奇怪的 MacBook 是 13 英寸 MacBook Pro。从纯粹的逻辑角度来看，我认为苹果甚至不应该出售该设备。 M2 MacBook Air 更便宜、更轻，而且功能同样强大。研究一下Apple 13/14 英寸 MacBook 的技术规格比较页面，很难找到推荐 13 英寸 MacBook Pro 的理由。但我确实认为它的销量出奇的好。我的理论是，有一部分市场更适合 MacBook Air，但他们认为自己需要一台“Pro”MacBook。规格对他们来说并不重要——重要的是名字。或者也许 Touch Bar 粉丝数量惊人？ ↩︎

entry.title: ★ 新款 Apple Pencil 配备 USB-C 端口，我的思绪转向整个 iPad 产品线的复杂性

entry.content:
似乎每家公司都在争先恐后地在人工智能淘金热中占据一席之地—— 克罗格的首席执行官承诺将法学硕士带入乳制品领域。一线工作人员也在效仿——尝试人工智能，以便他们可以更快地工作并做得更多。

自 ChatGPT 推出以来的短短几个月内，市场上已经出现了数百种人工智能驱动的工具。但是，虽然基于人工智能的工具具有真正有用的应用程序，但它们也带来了严重的安全风险。不幸的是，大多数公司仍然没有拿出管理这些风险的政策。在缺乏关于负责任的人工智能使用的明确指导的情况下，员工会漫不经心地将敏感数据交给不值得信赖的工具。

基于人工智能的浏览器扩展最清楚地说明了这一现象。 Chrome 商店中充斥着（声称）利用 ChatGPT 执行各种任务的扩展：发送电子邮件、设计图形、转录会议和编写代码。但这些工具容易出现至少三种类型的风险。

  1. 恶意软件：安全研究人员不断发现窃取用户数据的基于人工智能的扩展。这些扩展程序利用了用户对大型科技平台的信任（“如果 Google 允许它出现在 Chrome 商店中，那不会有危险！”），而且它们通常通过连接 ChatGPT 等人的 API 来发挥作用。
  2. 数据治理：包括苹果和威瑞森在内的公司已禁止其员工使用法学硕士，因为这些产品很少能保证用户的输入不会被用作培训数据。
  3. 即时注入攻击：在这种鲜为人知但可能无法解决的攻击中，网页上的隐藏文本指示人工智能工具执行恶意操作，例如窃取数据，然后删除记录。

到目前为止，大多数公司都被人工智能打了个措手不及，但这些风险太严重了，不容忽视。

在 Kolide，我们采用两部分方法来管理人工智能的使用。

  1. 以团队形式起草人工智能政策。我们不想完全禁止我们的团队使用人工智能，我们只是想安全地使用它。因此，我们的第一步是与多个团队的代表会面，了解他们从基于人工智能的工具中获得了什么，以及我们如何为他们提供不暴露关键数据或基础设施的安全选项。
  2. 使用 Kolide 阻止恶意工具。 Kolide 让 IT 和安全团队编写检测设备合规性问题的检查，我们已经开始为基于人工智能的恶意（或可疑）工具创建检查。现在，如果员工不小心下载了恶意软件，他们将无法登录我们的云应用程序，直到他们将其删除。

每家公司都必须根据自己独特的需求和关注点制定政策，但重要的是现在就开始。在人工智能卷走你公司的数据之前，我们还有时间抓住它的控制权。

Piper Sandler 对 9,000 多名美国青少年进行的调查得出了显着的结果：

  • 70% 的青少年在过去六个月内使用过 Spotify（高于 68%），其中 46% 的青少年选择订阅/付费购买 Spotify（高于 44%）

  • 青少年每日视频消费的 28.7% 在 Netflix 上（-220 bps，与 spring '23 相比），29.1% 在 YouTube 上（+100 bps，与 spring '23 相比）

  • 87% 的青少年拥有 iPhone； 88% 的人预计 iPhone 将成为他们的下一部手机； 34% 的人拥有 Apple Watch

从我记事起，iPhone 在美国青少年中的市场份额就一直非常高。不过，多年前，实际拥有iPhone 的青少年人数与想要为下一部手机购买 iPhone 的青少年人数之间存在分歧。现在这些数字实际上是偶数。我怀疑这是 iPhone 在美国市场份额持续增长的主要推动力。人们很容易只考虑短期情况，并相信几乎每个可能拥有手机的人都已经拥有了一部，但也有青少年（以及青少年）。青少年）每天都会得到他们的第一部手机。

青少年每天在 YouTube 上观看视频的时间略多于在 Netflix 上观看视频的时间，这并不奇怪，至少如果您最近观察过任何青少年的话。但考虑到他们的商业模式有多么不同，这是相当值得注意的。 Netflix 在新的原创内容和旧的库内容上花费了大量资金。 YouTube 内容大部分是由用户和内容创作者免费上传的。

我很想知道青少年使用哪些设备在不同服务上观看视频之间是否存在明显的差异。比如，也许 YouTube 观看更倾向于在 iPhone 上观看，但 Netflix 更倾向于在笔记本电脑和 iPad 等大屏幕设备上观看？毫无疑问，TikTok、Snapchat 和 Instagram 几乎全部是在 iPhone 上观看的。

entry.title: 古尔曼：苹果正在准备系统，将软件更新应用于仍在包装盒中的 iPhone
entry.content:

在所有事物中，清晰度是审美成就的最高境界。 The best link presentation is the one that makes it the most clear where it will take you. What X is presenting today is obfuscating, not clarifying, and thus grotesque.

entry.summary: Pixel phone photography is racing ahead to a world where images reflect moments that never actually were.
entry.content:
The Verge, as usual, has a wonderful page summarizing everything announced or demoed at yesterday's Pixel event , including a 15-minute summary video . The Verge is so good at things like this, I dare describe them as indispensable.

At the highest level it's impossible not to draw a direct comparison to Apple's iPhone 15 event last month. The two companies announced the exact same slate of products:

  • New flagship phones, both Pro and non-pro
  • New smartwatches
  • New wireless earbuds with AR noise filtering features

New phones, new watches, new earbuds. The Apple and Google versions of these products are all direct competitors to each other. No normal person buys both an iPhone and a Pixel, or both an Apple Watch and Pixel Watch, or both AirPods Pro and Pixel Buds Pro. But it's more profound than that. Practically speaking, no one mixes and matches these products. Why would anyone? If you own an iPhone, it's hard to think of a single reason why you'd try to pair it with a Pixel Watch or Pixel Buds. And if your phone is a Pixel, you can't even pair it with an Apple Watch.

As I wrote about Apple's event last month, these three product categories go together. They form an ecosystem of truly personal computing devices: the ones we take with us nearly everywhere, which work together in ways that just don't apply to other devices. There are zillions of people who own the Apple triumvirate — iPhone, Apple Watch, AirPods — who use a PC laptop and something other than an Apple TV box for streaming. And there are surely plenty of Android users who use a MacBook. A Mac can be a great device for use in Google's overall ecosystem.

It's also impossible not to comment on just how much less interest there is in Google's Pixel ecosystem. Google's event garnered only a sliver of the attention Apple's did, and their devices, similarly, have only a fraction of the sales Apple's do. On the one hand I'm tempted to say the difference is just commensurate with how much better at hardware Apple is than Google. But I think there's more to it than that. There's something ineffable about it. There are aspects of marketshare traction — in any market — that can't be explained by side-by-side product comparisons alone.

For a long time, Apple just couldn't regain traction in the PC market. Even after Mac OS X was released, even after the Jobs/Ive regime had restored both sense and panache to the hardware lineup, it seemed like the best Apple could do was tread water, marketshare-wise. But they kept at it. We remember the long-running “Get a Mac” ad campaign with Justin Long (“I'm a Mac”) and John Hodgman (“and I'm a PC”) not just because it was clever but because it really did coincide with a reversal of fortune for the Mac in the market. People really did start switching from Windows PCs. So great was Windows's market share that here we are 17 years after the start of that ad campaign and the Mac continues to grow .

Are Google's Pixel devices — the phones especially — ever going to have such a moment? I just don't see it happening. Most tellingly, they don't even take much share of the US Android market, let alone the US smartphone market, let alone the worldwide phone market. Here's 9to5Google, reporting back in July regarding a market share report from Counterpoint :

Through that, though, Apple actually managed to up its share of the overall US smartphone market in Q2 2023 by 10%. That takes the iPhone to a 55% share of overall shipments, with Android brands competing for the remaining 45%. Apple has had higher numbers prior, hitting 57% in Q4 of last year, but there's still a clear trend where Android is continuing to lose ground.

However, Google Pixel managed to be a bright spot throughout. Pixel shipments in the US grew by 48% year-over-year in Q2, the only major brand that managed to do so. That's still a mere 3% of shipments over the quarter, but that's also during a time where only a single Pixel device actually launched.

3 percent market share in the US — Pixel's best market — is a pretty dim “bright spot”. I don't know how anyone could compute this, other than anecdata observed in Mountain View cafeterias, but I'd wager that more Google employees carry an iPhone than carry a Pixel. There was a trend on Threads last week where — inspired by Linda Yaccarino showing the world that she didn't have the X app on her iPhone's home screen — people were showing screenshots of their own home screens. It struck me, watching them scroll by, just how many people have multiple Google apps among their most-used iOS apps — Maps, Gmail, Chrome. That's a sign of strength for Google, as a company, but it's obviously a hindrance to getting iPhone users invested in Google's overall ecosystem to switch their phone to a Pixel. The best software from Google is available on all phones; the best from Apple is only available on iPhones. 1

Something is just missing from the Pixel's potential appeal, and I don't think it was announced yesterday. I really am glad that Google seemingly remains committed to its Pixel devices, but I just don't see the angle that's going to change their popularity. I suspect I could save this column and publish it a year from now instead of today, and barely change a word.

The most striking features Google announced yesterday were regarding AI-assisted photography . “Magic Editor” lets you move and remove objects and people. “Best Take” is a feature I've long wished for yet still feel uneasy about: if you snap multiple photos of a group of people, Best Take will choose the “best” face for each person from the group of images, merging them into a single, well, best take. For decades we've all been able to do this manually using Photoshop and other image editors, and merging multiple image captures into a single resulting “photo” is how features like HDR work. But Google seems more willing to brush aside any ethical concerns about what exactly a photograph is. On Threads, Nilay Patel wrote :

Google is framing its new AI camera tools as making “memories” not photos which... run this to the end and it's just a camera designed to tell lies about what really happened. I don't know that any news organization can accept journalistic photos from a Pixel 8 at this point.

The difference from something like HDR is that even if HDR is generating one image from multiple sensor readings, the purpose is to more accurately reflect what the photographer's eyes actually saw, from that vantage point, at that moment in time. Pixel phone photography is racing ahead to a world where images reflect moments that never actually were. Is the purpose of a camera to capture things as they were, or as they should have been?

Is that dishonest? Is all of digital photography headed in this direction, inevitably, and Google is just willing to blaze the trail that everyone else will soon enough follow?我不知道。 But it was the segment of yesterday's event that most struck me: technically impressive, but ethically blithe.

  1. Try this on for an analogy: Google treats its entire Pixel portfolio like Apple treats Apple TV hardware. They make the best parts of it available on other platforms, greatly reducing the perceived value of their own hardware. Why switch to a Pixel when almost all of Google's apps are available on iOS? Why switch to an Apple TV box when the TV app and iTunes Store are built into your “smart” TV? ↩︎

entry.summary: Blaming it on the new titanium frame was just wild speculation on Kuo's part, and by all evidence is *completely wrong*.
entry.content:
On Tuesday, Ming-Chi Kuo published a short post under the headline “ The iPhone 15 Pro Series Overheating Issues Are Unrelated to TSMC's Advanced 3nm Node ”:

My survey indicates that the iPhone 15 Pro series overheating issues are unrelated to TSMC's advanced 3nm node. The primary cause is more likely the compromises made in the thermal system design to achieve a lighter weight, such as the reduced heat dissipation area and the use of a titanium frame, which negatively impacts thermal efficiency. It's expected that Apple will address this through software updates, but improvements may be limited unless Apple lowers processor performance. If Apple does not properly address this issue, it could negatively impact shipments over the product life cycle of the iPhone 15 Pro series.

That was the whole post. The post clearly implies that iPhone 15 Pro models have a design flaw related to their titanium frame that leads to overheating, and that since the flaw is related to the hardware design, Apple will be forced to throttle the CPU and GPU, and thus sales of the 15 Pro models will suffer.

Kuo is very influential, and thus his report drove Apple's stock price down noticeably . Kuo's influence stems not from his intuition but from his sources, but that's the problem with an allegation like this one. Kuo's narrative gained enough traction that Apple has issued a statement, repeated in its entirety below:

We have identified a few conditions which can cause iPhone to run warmer than expected. The device may feel warmer during the first few days after setting up or restoring the device because of increased background activity. We have also found a bug in iOS 17 that is impacting some users and will be addressed in a software update. Another issue involves some recent updates to third-party apps that are causing them to overload the system. We're working with these app developers on fixes that are in the process of rolling out.

Not only is the titanium frame of the iPhone 15 Pro models not an issue, cooling-wise, but Apple told me — and I have no reason to doubt — that the iPhone 15 Pro and Pro Max are better at heat dissipation than any previous iPhone that used a stainless steel frame (iPhone X, XS, and 11–14 Pro). There is absolutely nothing wrong — and in fact much that is good — with the heat dissipation of the titanium frame, and Apple has no plan to in any way throttle the A17's performance. They have bugs to fix in iOS 17, that is all.

It's long been true that iPhones sometimes get warm/hot during the first few days after setup (or complete restore): all sorts of large libraries (like Photos) get synced in the background, and all sorts of on-device processing takes place. There are also often performance-related bugs in the first release of the major new iOS version each fall — and per Apple's statement, this year is no exception.

As for the problematic third-party apps, one of them is Instagram, which has apparently just this week released a version fixing a bug that was so egregious that it was burning through iPhones' battery life at a rate of 1 percent/minute just sitting idle. YouTuber Faruk “iPhonedo” Korkmaz posted a video this week showing the buggy version of Instagram heating two different iPhones to 100°F: one an iPhone 15 Pro, the other a year-old iPhone 14 Pro. Exact same overheating issue. (I question here why iOS allows any app to consume so many resources that it makes the device too hot to hold comfortably, but the bug was apparently Instagram's. Same too with Uber . Real shocker that two apps made with a Frankensteinian mishmash of web and native UI toolkits would run amok, resource-wise.)

Ming-Chi Kuo obviously has some remarkable sources within Apple's Asian supply chain. But he's still sometimes very wrong . And — unlike Mark Gurman — Kuo's sources seemingly never come from within Apple itself. His post on this overheating issue is almost transparently a leak from TSMC — a sort of “ Whatever is going on with the iPhone 15 Pro heat dissipation, it has nothing to do with our 3nm process ”. Blaming it on the new titanium frame was just wild speculation on Kuo's part, and by all evidence is completely wrong .

If Kuo has any respect for accuracy or truth, as I'm sure he does, he'll issue a full retraction.

entry.summary: 《华尔街日报》告诉我们，苹果芯片很容易，但蜂窝调制解调器尤其困难。
entry.content:
Aaron Tilley 和 Yang Jie 为《华尔街日报》进行报道，标题并非标题党的标题“苹果为其新 iPhone 制造关键部件的惨败内幕”（ News+ 链接）：

上周推出的新 iPhone 机型缺少苹果公司花费数年时间和数十亿美元试图及时开发的专有硅芯片。 2018 年，苹果首席执行官蒂姆·库克 (Tim Cook) 下达了设计和制造调制解调器芯片（将 iPhone 与无线运营商连接的部件）的命令，导致雇用了数千名工程师。其目标是切断苹果公司对高通公司的勉强依赖，高通公司是一家长期主导调制解调器市场的芯片供应商。

上述领导正确地奠定了基础，如果有什么不同的话，那就是低估了苹果和高通之间的竞争。高通确实在调制解调器芯片市场占据主导地位，但这甚至可能说得太温和了——它们实际上是优质 5G 蜂窝调制解调器芯片的唯一竞争者。苹果公司在蜂窝调制解调器方面对高通的依赖不仅仅是令人嫉妒的，更是令人鄙视的。即使苹果和高通相处融洽，苹果也会面临核心技术依赖单一公司的问题。但苹果和高通根本相处不来。

但上述故事之后的一切充其量都是可疑的，而且在某些方面，这是一个荒谬且相当透明的热门作品。听起来像是高通公司给蒂利和杰提供的，尽管存在明显的问题，但他们还是买下了它。

苹果公司原计划将其调制解调器芯片准备在新的 iPhone 机型中使用。但去年年底的测试发现该芯片速度太慢并且容易过热。它的电路板太大了，足有半个iPhone，无法使用。

这根本没有任何意义。这是一个不可能的场景。这听起来像是 Twitter/X 上匿名巨魔的言论，而不是《华尔街日报》的报道。但这是《华尔街日报》报道的，让我们想想这一段话有多么可笑。

首先，时间线并没有加起来。我们不仅应该相信苹果“去年年底”只是在测试 iPhone 15 调制解调器芯片的可行性，而且该芯片“太大了，会占据半部 iPhone，使其无法使用” 。诚然，“占据半部iPhone”的调制解调器芯片将无法使用，但为什么会考虑在今年的手机中使用这样的芯片呢？它可能是世界上功能最好的 5G 调制解调器——性能更快、效率更高——但如果这么大，它根本无法使用。还差得很远。看看iPhone 14 的拆解，就知道高通的 X65 调制解调器芯片组有多小。

当然有可能“去年年底”苹果测试了苹果设计的蜂窝调制解调器的原型，该原型很大，性能缓慢，而且运行温度太高。这就是组件开发的工作原理：在早期的大型原型中，功能性是第一位的，其次是小型化。您不必是一名系统工程师也能明白这其中的道理。为什么要浪费时间来对一个尚不清楚工作性能的组件进行小型化呢？ 1

但他们不可能在今年的iPhone 上测试这样的东西。硬件的交付时间是几年而不是几个月。而且由于苹果每年需要生产数亿部新 iPhone，因此 iPhone 硬件设计的交付时间比大多数产品更长，而不是更短。苹果今天不仅知道明年的 iPhone 16 型号中将使用蜂窝调制解调器，而且他们可能已经决定了两年后的 iPhone 17 的调制解调器以及几乎所有其他东西。

苹果尚未公开承认其调制解调器项目，更不用说其缺点了，据估计，苹果去年已向高通支付了超过 72 亿美元的芯片费用。

Apple 2019 年新闻稿：“ Apple 将收购英特尔智能手机调制解调器业务的大部分。”我不知道他们如何能比这更清楚地认可这个项目。

回到日记：

这些人士表示，由于技术挑战、沟通不畅以及经理们对于尝试设计芯片而不是购买芯片是否明智的问题存在分歧，苹果调制解调器芯片的工程团队工作进展缓慢。美国和国外的团队被孤立在不同的小组中，没有全球领导者。一些经理不鼓励工程师传播有关延误或挫折的坏消息，从而导致不切实际的目标和拖延的最后期限。

从这里开始，《华尔街日报》的故事开始有点像高通编造的故事。我们不知道高通是幕后黑手，但我们确实知道，高通在 iPhone 发布会前一天发布了一份有关两家公司之间续签协议的新闻稿，给苹果的调制解调器努力蒙上了阴影。在 iPhone 15 上市前一天，有一个新故事描绘了苹果调制解调器团队内部技术无能和管理混乱的情况，还有什么比这更好的跟进方式呢？如果高通担心自己的工程人才流失，这种说法尤其适合高通。

“仅仅因为苹果生产了地球上最好的芯片，就认为他们也可以生产调制解调器，这是荒谬的，”前苹果无线主管 Jaydeep Ranade 说，他于 2018 年（该项目开始的那一年）离开了公司。

《华尔街日报》的第一个消息来源是一位前苹果员工，他承认在开始自己的调制解调器项目之前就离开了公司，他敏锐的洞察力是，一家擅长某件事的公司可能不擅长完全不同的事情。

知情人士称，预计苹果要到 2025 年末才会生产类似的芯片。这些人士表示，可能还会有进一步的延误，但该公司相信最终会成功。

如果苹果预计要到“2025 年末”才能生产出与高通相当的 5G 调制解调器芯片，那么他们为什么要在 2022 年测试一款芯片，希望将其应用到今天的 iPhone 15 中呢？一个还不到四年的项目突然比计划晚了四年？这个故事本身就反驳了自己。

苹果公司发现，相比之下，设计微处理器（本质上是一台运行软件的微型计算机）很容易。传输和接收无线数据的调制解调器芯片必须符合严格的连接标准，才能为世界各地的无线运营商提供服务。

“这些延误表明苹果没有预料到这项工作的复杂性，”长期担任高通前高管的塞尔吉·维伦内格 (Serge Willenegger) 表示，他于 2018 年离开公司，并不了解苹果芯片的当前状态。 “蜂窝网络是一个怪物。”

第二位消息人士是一位退休高管，他的整个职业生涯都在高通度过，他敏锐的洞察力强调，高通作为无可争议的行业领导者的领域非常困难。

苹果公司在十多年前就致力于生产更多用于其产品的各种半导体。 2010年，该公司开始在iPhone和iPad中使用自己的处理芯片。这些芯片帮助苹果超越了许多 Android 竞争对手，后者依赖高通、台湾联发科和其他制造商的芯片。

苹果芯片的性能优于“许多安卓竞争对手”？请分享它没有表现出色的那些。但那些 A 系列芯片很“简单”。

该公司于 2020 年开始用专有芯片替换 Mac 电脑中使用多年的英特尔处理器芯片，该芯片使其笔记本电脑运行速度更快，产生的热量更少，这些改进有助于提振萎靡不振的 Mac 销量。 Apple 芯片还为公司在每台电脑上节省了约 75 至 150 美元。

苹果广受好评的 M 系列芯片无疑有助于 Mac 的销售，但说 Mac 的销售“落后”于英特尔的说法是错误的。事实上，Apple 芯片型号首次亮相之前的最后一个季度（即 2020 年第三季度）的 Mac 销量在当时是 Mac 有史以来最好的销售季度。尽管苹果公司已于当年 6 月在 WWDC 上宣布了芯片转型。在更换之前， Mac 就打破了历史销售记录。

苹果公司将其调制解调器芯片项目命名为“Sinope”，以希腊神话中智胜宙斯的仙女命名。苹果前人力资源主管兼 BraveCore 咨询公司联合创始人克里斯·迪弗 (Chris Deaver) 表示，在库克、斯鲁吉和其他人指示苹果打造自己的无线组件后，该计划于 2018 年开始成形。

迪弗是《华尔街日报》报道中第三位点名的消息人士，他于 2015 年至 2019 年在苹果公司从事人力资源工作，并与人合着了一本即将出版的书，其预购描述如下：“来自帮助蒂姆·库克将苹果从‘思考’转型的思想领袖。 “不同的”到“一起以不同的方式工作”——这是一本及时的指南，可以帮助领导者变得更有创造力，并帮助有创造力的人成为更好的领导者”。您永远猜不到书封套的调色板。 2

2019 年 12 月，Srouji 飞往慕尼黑迎接苹果新收购的英特尔无线员工。据观看会议的人士称，他在一次聚会上表示，调制解调器芯片项目将改变苹果的游戏规则，是公司发展的下一步。他表示，该芯片将使苹果设备与众不同，就像苹果处理器所做的那样。

随着苹果公司用英特尔工程师和从高通聘请的其他人员填补了该项目的空缺，公司高管设定了一个目标，即在 2023 年秋季准备好调制解调器芯片。该项目的许多无线专家很快就意识到，实现这一目标是不可能的。

因此，苹果希望自己的蜂窝调制解调器能够适用于今年的 iPhone 15，是在 2019 年，而不是“去年年底”。同样，这全部来自同一份《华尔街日报》的报道。

苹果公司发现，采用数千名工程师的蛮力（这一策略在设计智能手机和笔记本电脑的计算机大脑方面取得了成功）并不足以快速生产出卓越的调制解调器芯片。

这里的含义是，苹果芯片是由众所周知的在无限打字机上打字的无限猴子设计的——这与布鲁克斯定律完全矛盾。

调制解调器芯片的制造比处理芯片更棘手，因为它们必须与 5G 无线网络以及世界各国使用的 2G、3G 和 4G 网络无缝协作，每个网络都有自己的技术特点。 Apple 微处理器运行专为其 iPhone 和笔记本电脑设计的软件程序。

这个故事一次又一次地强调 SoC（包括 CPU、GPU、神经处理单元等）很简单，但蜂窝调制解调器却特别困难。本段中荒谬的说法是，世界各地网络的多样性使蜂窝调制解调器变得困难，而苹果的 CPU 则变得更容易，因为它们只需要执行“专为 iPhone 和笔记本电脑设计的”软件。让我们先抛开这个笨拙的措辞忽略了手表、平板电脑和台式电脑等外形因素的事实，而考虑一下 Apple 芯片的性能如此之高，通过 Rosetta 2 翻译（我确信这项技术也很容易制造），有史以来最慢的Apple 芯片 Mac（配备 8 GB RAM 的 M1 MacBook Air）运行为 Intel 处理器编译的软件的速度比 Apple 推出的任何 Intel Mac 都要快。苹果芯片不仅不专门运行为其“设计”的软件，它还比英特尔自己的芯片更好地运行为英特尔芯片编译的软件。

前项目工程师表示，没有无线芯片经验的苹果高管设定了不切实际的紧迫时间表。团队必须构建芯片的原型版本并证明它们可以与全球许多无线运营商合作，这是一项耗时的工作。

这里的第二句话意味着苹果的调制解调器项目主管并没有想到他们需要构建原型，或者全球运营商认证会很耗时 - 因为我确信苹果在所有支持的运营商中获得 iPhone 认证并不困难在 2019 年该项目开始之前。

苹果去年年底测试了其原型机后，高管们更好地理解了这一挑战。据知情人士透露，结果并不理想。这些芯片基本上比高通最好的调制解调器芯片晚了三年。使用它们可能会导致 iPhone 的无线速度比竞争对手慢。

该公司取消了在苹果 2023 年机型中使用该芯片的计划，并将计划的推出时间推迟到 2024 年。最终，苹果高管意识到该公司也无法实现这一目标。苹果公司与高通展开谈判，以继续供应调制解调器芯片。苹果与高通的许可协议将于 2025 年 4 月到期，不过可以再延长两年。

“去年底”苹果仍然希望在今年的 iPhone 中使用自己的蜂窝调制解调器，这一想法是多么愚蠢，我怎么强调都不为过。

以下是《华尔街日报》所宣称的“惊人的失败”：高端蜂窝调制解调器是非常难以设计的重要组件，而高通拥有整个市场。苹果在 2019 年以 10 亿美元收购了英特尔的第二梯队调制解调器业务，并制定了一个雄心勃勃的目标，即到 2023 年生产自己的调制解调器，使其与高通的调制解调器相匹配或超过高通。他们错过了最佳情况目标，因此仍在从高通购买调制解调器，并将至少在接下来的一两年内继续这样做。这不仅不是“令人震惊的失败”，而且连一个字都算不上新闻。

据参与该项目的人士称，苹果公司有足够的现金和意愿继续开发其调制解调器芯片。 “苹果不会放弃，”Charter Equity Research 董事总经理、无线行业专家爱德华·斯奈德 (Edward Snyder) 表示。 “他们讨厌高通的活生生的胆量。”

最后，这个被诅咒的故事中的一位知情人士说了一些准确的话。

  1. 例如，考虑一下彭博社 Mark Gurman 2 月份关于苹果公司为 Apple Watch 发明血糖监测仪的进展的报告中的这段话：

    知情人士表示，苹果公司的系统经过 12 年多的开发，目前被认为处于概念验证阶段。由于该项目属于机密，因此不愿透露姓名。该公司相信该技术是可行的，但需要缩小到更实用的尺寸。

    工程师们正在努力开发一款 iPhone 大小的原型设备，可以绑在人的二头肌上。与桌面系统的早期版本相比，这将是一个显着的减少。

    这就是原型的工作原理。但没有人板着脸提议明年的 Apple Watch 可能配备 iPhone 大小的血糖监测仪。 ↩︎

  2. 一个月前，Deaver 在 LinkedIn 上宣布了这本书，他的帖子上的一条评论写道：“感谢您尽早浏览您的书 Chris 🙏🏽😊 这非常有洞察力 👏🏽👌🏽”。该评论来自……Jaydeep Ranade，《华尔街日报》报道中的第二位点名消息来源。这足以让一个愤世嫉俗的人认为，亚伦·蒂利（Aaron Tilley）只是在 LinkedIn 上点击一下，就可以找到心怀不满、愿意透露消息来源的前员工。但我确信故事中的四位消息来源之一碰巧评论了另一位消息人士的 LinkedIn 帖子，这只是一个巧合。 ↩︎︎

entry.title: ★ 更喜欢 Craptalar

entry.summary: 钛金属、计算摄影技术的进步、操作按钮以及名为“USB-C”的创新连接器。
entry.content:
等等，大多数人不会每年升级他们的手机，所以我们不应该根据同比比较来审查新手机。但是，我每年都会买一部新 iPhone。你们中的很多人可能也这样做。因此，让我们对 iPhone 15 Pro 和去年的 14 Pro 进行直接比较。经过不到一周的测试（以 iPhone 15 Pro Max 为主要选择），我有四个理由考虑升级。

Titanium

我把它放在第一位，甚至放在相机上方。相机的改进是客观的。钛金属与顶级 iPhone 之前的材料（抛光不锈钢）之间的差异在很多方面都是主观的。但重量的减轻和手感的改善却是非常显着的。每个人使用手机的方式都不同。有些人从不用手机拍照或拍摄视频。但每个人都随身携带并持有iPhone。对于手持工具来说，让它成为手中更好的物品是一个巨大的胜利。

我们回避承认这一点，至少最近是这样，但对小玩意的渴望是真实存在的。人们被精美的物品和优质的材料所吸引。新车、新相机、新手表（或者新买的旧手表）。早在苹果进入这个行业之前，手机就已经开始玩这个游戏了。如果您足够大，您一定会记得第一次看到摩托罗拉 Razr 的情景。他们突然关上的方式。很酷的按钮。我记得我当时想，天哪，太酷了。在那个时代之前， 这很酷。

我认为苹果在六代产品（从 2017 年的 iPhone X 到去年的 14 Pro）中使用不锈钢没有任何原因，除了它看起来很酷，而且看起来很高档。正如我去年在评测 iPhone 14 Pro 时所写的那样，“它的抛光度很高，看起来确实很漂亮，但钢实在是太重了。”

我们长期以来关于 iPhone 过重的全国噩梦已经结束。

钛金属在各方面都是升级版。首先，它使设备变得更加轻。我一直在测试所有四款新 iPhone 机型，无论是 Pro 版还是非 Pro 版，虽然 Pro 版比相应的使用铝制框架的非 Pro 版重了几克，但拿在手里的重量差异可以忽略不计。为了并排比较相机，我带着三部手机走来走去——新款 iPhone 15 Pro Max 和常规 15 Pro，以及我用了一年的 14 Pro——而且我必须将不同材料制成的手机壳放在不同的手机上。我把手机放在口袋里来区分它们，因为新款 15 Pro Max 的重量与去年的常规尺寸 14 Pro差不多。虽然重量不一样，但却出奇的接近：221 克与 206 克。新款普通尺寸 15 Pro 的重量仅为 187 克，而铝制 iPhone 15 的重量为 171 克。但这些重量数值并不能体现出正确的感觉。与它们所取代的不锈钢 iPhone Pro 机型相比，这些新款钛金属 iPhone Pro给人的感觉明显更轻、平衡性更好。

我也非常喜欢这些新型钛金属框架的外观和触感。我评测的 15 Pro Max 是天然钛金属材质，15 Pro 是蓝色的。两人都相当帅气。 （蓝色钛金属与 Midnight MacBook Air 非常相配。）当然，抛光不锈钢很不错，但它与我将 iPhone 作为工具（就像传统相机一样）的想法不符。你不会看到由不锈钢制成的高端相机——太重、太抛光。 iPhone 15 Pro 的钛金属框架的表面处理非常出色。它很优雅，不是工业化的，但它传达了一种让我们开始工作的严肃性。仅就纯粹的手感而言，我更喜欢 11-14 型号的非专业版 iPhone。现在，我显然更喜欢 15 Pro 机型的手感。这是自可爱的iPhone 5和5S以来 iPhone 的最佳手感，十年前 iPhone 还只是一个小东西。从外观上看，有纹理的钛金属有点让人想起 iPhone 4 和 4S 的拉丝不锈钢。

侧面按钮、音量按钮和操作按钮都具有良好的点击性，并且不会晃动。按钮边缘清晰但不锋利。

即使您像许多人一样，在购买 iPhone 的那天就把它放入保护壳中，直到您将其从保护壳中取出以换新的那一天之前，再也看不到或摸不到钛金属，您还是赢了，因为你的 iPhone 15 Pro 将会变得更轻、更平衡。对于我们这些大多数甚至只是大部分时间都没有表壳的人来说，钛金属的外观和感觉是一个主观的胜利。但即使对于总是戴着外套的人来说，这也是减肥方面不可否认的胜利。

Apple 首次在2001 年 PowerBook G4 的产品背面使用钛合金，这款笔记本电脑至今仍定义了 Apple 笔记本电脑的基本圆形直线形状和金属表面。对于一台已有 22 年历史的电脑来说，这台机器看起来仍然非常现代，但没过多久，苹果就放弃了钛金属，改用铝金属。当时，苹果公司的材料科学能力还没有准备好使用钛——那些 PowerBook 是经过喷漆的，随着时间的推移，油漆会剥落。我认为，正如手表收藏家所说，它们老化得很好，形成了铜绿，但它们老化了，而且老化得很快。

苹果本质上是一家计算机公司，但材料工程是该公司的重要部门。我们听 Jony Ive 讲述的有关铝制和一体式机身结构的介绍视频有多少年了？我们现在认为一体式笔记本电脑框架是理所当然的——它们是整个行业几乎所有高质量笔记本电脑的制造方式——但它在推出时是一项革命性的技术。

苹果对其在 iPhone 15 Pro 中使用钛金属感到非常自豪，上周的主题演讲的整个部分都是由材料科学工程师Isabel Yang发表的。这是一个重大突破，尤其是考虑到苹果生产所有 iPhone 机型（尤其是 Pro 机型）所需的规模。长期以来，我一直怀疑 Apple Watch 的 Edition 型号一直是他们有一天可能在大批量生产的设备中使用的材料的试验场。陶瓷可以说是苹果有史以来制造的最漂亮的手表，但似乎没有任何进展——甚至从未有传言称它是 iPhone 的潜在材料。然而，系列 5-7 的钛合金版手表给我的印象是，这些设备为去年的 Apple Watch Ultra 以及现在的苹果产品线之王 iPhone Pro 铺平了道路。

这是一个令人振奋的成功，为现代（后 X）iPhone 时代带来了迄今为止最好的手感，并且是任何竞争手机制造商都无法比拟的。顶级 Android 手机采用苹果的中端材料铝制成。钛金属的功能更好——它更坚固——而且同样重要的是，它真的太酷了。

Cameras

今年 iPhone 15 机型共有三项主要的新相机功能。 1首先是对主摄像头的重大升级（覆盖 1×-2× 光学范围的摄像头）。其次，肖像模式实现了自该功能推出以来最大的同比改进。第三，15 Pro Max 独有的是新型 5 倍长焦摄像头，等效视野为 120 毫米。 （普通15 Pro的长焦仍为3×/77mm；非Pro iPhone 15没有长焦镜头。）

先说主相机。去年，苹果为 14 Pro 主摄像头引入了新的 48 兆像素传感器。默认情况下它仍然生成 12MP 图像，将 48MP 传感器聚集成“四像素”矩阵。传感器上每个 2×2 正方形的 4 个原生像素用于创建图像的 1 个像素。这项技术以细节换取额外的光敏感度。您可以选择使用 iPhone 14 Pro 拍摄 ProRAW 以获得 48MP 图像，但这确实是一项专业功能。我认为自己是一名半严肃的专业消费者摄影师，但说到拍摄格式，我的拍摄非常简单——使用内置相机应用程序和默认格式 (HEIF)。我非常关心我的照片，但我真的只是傻瓜式拍摄。

去年，iPhone 14 Pro 的三个后置摄像头提供了四个“镜头”：0.5×、1×、2× 和 3×。 0.5×是超广角硬件相机。 3×是长焦。不过，1× 和 2× “镜头”都来自同一个主相机。在 1 倍时，相机系统对整个 48MP 相机传感器进行四联装；在 2 倍时，它使用来自相机传感器中心的 12 MP 裁剪。结果是，对于 2× 照片，您仍然得到 12MP 图像，其细节和分辨率比以 1× 拍摄然后在后期裁剪到图像中心时获得的更多细节和分辨率。

今年的 iPhone 15 Pro，超广角和长焦的情况类似，只不过 Pro Max 上的长焦是 5 倍而不是 3 倍。但 15 Pro 机型主摄像头的“光子引擎”图像处理管道今年更加先进。苹果是这样描述的：

光子引擎在我们的图像管道中使用了新的 48MP 帧，使 iPhone 能够将最佳的低光（具有大四像素的 12MP 图像）与最佳的细节（具有单个像素的 48MP 图像）结合起来。这种方法是业界首创，它为主摄像头提供了新的默认分辨率 - 具有更多细节的 24MP 图像、出色的低光性能以及用户期望从 iPhone 摄像头获得的所有功能 - 深度融合、智能 HDR、实时照片和零快门延迟。

以 1 倍拍摄照片并与其他手机的 12MP 照片进行比较 - 放大时您会看到更多细节，尤其是在查看头发、皮肤或衣服纹理时。

实际上，这是计算摄影的下一代进步。借助四像素，您可以轻松了解 iPhone 14 Pro 如何从 48MP 传感器生成 12MP 图像。这是小学的划分：48 ÷ 4 = 12。但是15 Pro主摄像头没有24MP传感器。光子引擎为每张照片从传感器获取多张图像，包括用于细节的 48MP 图像和用于低光和降噪的 12MP 四像素图像，然后通过计算将它们融合在一起以生成单个 24MP 图像。 Apple is having its cake and eating it too, merging the benefits of a sensor with many small pixels with the benefits of a sensor with fewer large pixels. You don't need to know that this is happening, you just get more detail in your photos from the main camera.

I mentioned above that both the 1× and 2× “lenses” on the iPhone 14 Pro use the same physical main camera. With the iPhones 15 Pro, Apple has added additional virtual lenses:

  • 1.0× ≈ 24mm
  • 1.2× ≈ 28mm
  • 1.5× ≈ 35mm
  • 2.0× ≈ 48mm

When shooting HEIC or JPEG (ie when you're not shooting ProRAW), all focal ranges from 1.0 to 1.9 produce 24MP images. It's effectively using computational photography to do optical zoom in this range from a the fixed-length main camera. In a certain sense it's cropping, but it's far removed from any simplistic cropping. There's nothing magic about these particular stops between 1× and 2× other than the fact that 28 and 35mm equivalents have long been very popular focal lengths in traditional photography. You can “zoom” to any focal length between 1–1.9× and you'll still get a 24MP image: 1.4×, 1.7×, 1.9×, whatever. 1.2× and 1.5× get special treatment in the Camera app simply because 28 and 35mm equivalents are so popular, and I believe Apple's image processing pipeline is optimized for these lengths. [ Update: I originally wrote that you get 24MP images from 1.0–2.0×, but that was slightly mistaken — once you go from 1.9× to 2.0×, resolution drops to 12MP, presumably because at 2.0× the iPhone is using a precise center crop of the 48MP sensor.]

By default, when you repeatedly tap the 1× focal length button in the Camera app viewfinder, it cycles between 1.0/1.2/1.5×, and momentarily shows you the traditional equivalent after switching (24/28/35mm, respectively). You can adjust these options in the Camera section of the Settings app, including changing the default from 1× to 1.2× or 1.5×. For example, to simplify your options, you might consider turning off the preset for 1.2×/28mm, so that the 1× button in the viewfinder just toggles between 1.0 and 1.5×. I'm not sure what I want to do yet, personally, but I'm leaning toward keeping all three available, but changing my default to 1.5×/35mm, which I consider generally more natural looking for scenes and more flattering to human subjects.

You could always get the equivalent of these focal lengths by “zooming” to 1.2× or 1.5× in the Camera app, but now you keep more native resolution from the image sensor.

It's also worth noting that this improvement to the Photonic Engine comes to the non-pro iPhones 15 too, on their main camera, which also now sports a 48MP sensor. However, the non-pro iPhone 15 models don't get the feature that treats 1.2×/28mm and 1.5×/35mm as discrete “lenses”. And the hardware story is not as simple as “This year's non-pro iPhone 15 gets the 1× camera system from last year's iPhone 14 Pro”. The 1× lens on the iPhone 15 and 15 Plus is a 26mm equivalent focal distance; the 1× lens on the iPhone 14 Pro (and this year's 15 Pro models) is a 24mm equivalent. In my brief testing, the 1× hardware lens on the iPhone 15 models is noticeably inferior (or, if you prefer, less pro ) to that on the Pro models, including last year's iPhone 14 Pro. Shooting side-by-side in the same lighting, images from the iPhone 15 look flatter and lack vibrancy and contrast compared to those from the iPhone 15 (or 14) Pro. The camera system on the non-pro iPhones 15 seems fine, but if you care about photography, you want to get an iPhone Pro. It's not just that the iPhones Pro have a telephoto lens and the non-pro ones don't; the images from the main camera are noticeably better on iPhones Pro.

Another significant improvement this year is a much-improved Portrait mode. Apple claims improvements that boost detail and dynamic range, but the main improvement is that you no longer need to manually select Portrait mode before capturing. You can simply capture images using the regular still photo mode, and if a person, dog, or cat is detected, Portrait mode will be available via an “ƒ” button in the viewfinder, and you can toggle it off and on while shooting, and make adjustments to the background blur and focal distance in post. You get the same on-the-fly Portrait mode with the front-facing camera, too, on all iPhone 15 models.

I expect this to make a significant practical difference in my photography. In many situations, shooting candid pictures of friends and family, I just take out my iPhone, open the Camera app, frame the image, and start shooting — quickly and discreetly. When the moment feels fleeting, I don't feel like I have time to futz with a manual switch to Portrait mode. A quick check of my Photos library shows that out of about 2,800 photos I shot with the iPhone 14 Pro in the last year, 233 were in Portrait mode. Those are some of my favorite photos of the last year, but I expect to wind up with way more Portrait mode photos this year, thanks to the dynamic on-the-fly application of Portrait mode. It's a can't-lose feature, because if you're ever unhappy with the way a picture looks in Portrait mode, you can simply turn it off in post, and you'll wind up with the same image you would have had even if this automatic Portrait mode feature didn't exist.

Lastly, now seems like a good place to reiterate that these new features all work with zero shutter lag. To date this has been a hard and fast rule for Apple's Camera team — everything happens instantaneously, and can be previewed live in the viewfinder before you capture. It's intriguing to ponder what features Apple could enable if they allowed iPhones to “develop” photos for a few seconds after capture, but I think I understand why they don't. Once you allow some features to take post-capture processing time, it's a slippery slope to an overall camera experience that feels slow and laggy. The iPhone camera has always felt fast and snappy, and the iPhone 15 lineup is no exception.

That brings us to the elephant in the room: the 5× lens exclusive to the iPhone 15 Pro Max. If you prefer a larger iPhone, well, you're in luck, because you get that lens with the iPhone size you prefer. But if, like me, you prefer the regular-size iPhones, but, all things considered, would prefer the longest available telephoto lens, you have a decision to make.

Qualitatively the new 5× lens seems about as good as the recent 3× telephoto iPhone Pro lenses. Which is to say it's fine, for a telephoto lens on a tiny (relative to “real” cameras) phone, but it's nowhere near as good as the main camera. The 3D sensor-shift module seems to work like a charm to keep things stable — a real challenge at focal lengths like this. If you find yourself frequently wishing for more than 3× optical zoom with your current iPhone camera, you're probably going to like this 5× lens a lot.

Me, though, I just don't shoot many telephoto lens pictures or videos. Again, looking at my personal Photos library (and using Smart Albums to sort images by camera and lens ), out of roughly 2,800 photos I've taken with my iPhone 14 Pro, only 170 used the 3× telephoto lens. As a point of reference, 417 were shot with the ultra wide 0.5× lens, which includes all macro shots. Tallying up my lens usage for the last year reiterates my gut feeling: my ideal hypothetical iPhone might be an iPhone 15 Pro Mini, even if that meant having only two camera lenses instead of three, if those two cameras were the same 0.5× ultra wide and 1× main cameras as the actual iPhone 15 Pro models.

The biggest potential problem I might have with that hypothetical iPhone 15 Pro Mini of my dreams would be battery life, not the missing telephoto lens. I do occasionally use the telephoto lens I have, and I'm sure I will again this year, but not enough to justify an overall larger phone. Your mileage, of course, may vary. Some people love shooting with long lenses. Me, though, even when shooting with standalone cameras that use interchangeable lenses, I've only ever bought prime lenses in the 28mm to 50mm range. I zoom with my feet.

One hitch with the iPhone Pro Max having a 5× telephoto lens is that if you really want a 3-4× focal length for framing, it needs to be digitally zoomed from the main camera. In my testing this doesn't seem to make much difference, but more talented photographers might disagree. I tend to think that when I do want a long lens with extra reach, I might as well go really long.

In past years when the Plus-sized iPhones have had exclusive camera lenses, those lenses made their way down to the regular-size iPhones in the next model year. So I suspect Apple's plan is for next year's iPhone 16 Pro and Pro Max to both have 5× telephoto cameras based on this tetraprism design. I hope so, but if that doesn't happen and 5× remains exclusive to the Max, so be it. The main camera is where the action is for me — and that main camera has seen another terrific year-over-year upgrade with the 15 Pro models.

Action Button

It's a little thing, literally, but I dig the new Action button.

A decade ago I was bewildered by the fact that of all the things Android phone makers had shamelessly copied from the iPhone, the mute switch wasn't one of them. But then the iPad dropped its physical mute switch, and I could see the trade-off inherent to a physical switch: software control. With a physical mute switch, silent mode can't be controlled by software, because software can't flip the physical switch. (Carmakers, to name one common example, face this same dilemma with dashboard knobs and switches.) If a hardware button, knob, or switch has state, then that statefulness can't be controlled by software unless the software can push, twist, or flip the physical controls.

If you just want a mute toggle, the new Action button is, I think, as good if not better than the old mute switch. No matter what action you assign to the button, it activates with a long-press, but that long-press delay is pretty short — it's just long enough to avoid accidental activations, and is short enough that it never feels slow. When assigned to toggling silent mode, you get a quick series of haptic taps when it goes into silent mode, and one haptic tap when it goes out of silent mode. It's easy to tell the haptics apart, if you're using it without looking at it (like, say, if your iPhone is in your pocket or purse).

Because I've been spending a lot of time testing the new cameras, I've spent most of the last week with the Action button assigned to the Camera app. For many years now Apple has offered a shortcut to jump into the Camera app from the lock screen. There's a button you can long-press in the lower-right corner of the lock screen, but the quickest way is to swipe right-to-left anywhere on the lock screen. I went into this thinking I might leave my Action button set to toggle silent mode, on the grounds that we already have these shortcuts for jumping into the Camera app, but one thing that's become clear to me these past few days is that assigning the Action button to Camera is super useful when you want to jump to the Camera app while your iPhone is unlocked because you're already using it . It's cool and useful to have a button that always jumps you right into Camera no matter what state your iPhone is in.

So at the moment, I'm a bit torn between assigning my Action button to act as a mute switch or as a Camera launcher. Which brings me to another intriguing option: Shortcuts.

I created a simple workflow in Shortcuts that shows a menu with three options: Photo, Video, and Mute/Unmute. The Photo and Video options jump you to the corresponding shooting mode in the Camera app, and the Mute/Unmute option reverses the current setting for Silent mode. Shortcuts has built-in actions to enable and disable Silent mode on the device, but doesn't have a built-in way to get the current Silent mode state. For that, my shortcut uses an action from the excellent free (and aptly-named) Actions utility by Sindre Sorhus . When Silent mode is engaged, the command is “🔊 Unmute”; when Silent mode is off, the command is “🔇 Mute”. (Now that there isn't a physical switch to inspect, when Silent mode is engaged, the iPhones 15 Pro show a bell-with-line-through-it icon in the status bar , in the top left corner next to the time or carrier name. But it felt clever to make the menu item in my shortcut dynamically reflect the current state.) Here's the shortcut , if you're interested, and here's a screenshot showing it in, err, action.

Is a menu like this a good use of the Action button? I'm not sure yet, but it sure is fun. The iPhones 15 Pro now have a dedicated hardware button that anyone can program using Shortcuts.我喜欢它。 One DF reader emailed me last week wondering if you can assign the Action button to act like an old-school Home button. You can, with Shortcuts. I can't wait to see what others come up with.

[ Update: I made a better version of this shortcut . Instead of showing a menu you need to choose from, it opens the Camera app unless the phone is face down or upside down, in which cases it toggles the state of Silent mode. I've been using it this way for two days now and love it.]

USB-C

The overwhelming consensus seems to be that Apple only switched from Lightning to USB-C with the iPhones 15 due to the regulatory mandate from the EU. And, conversely, that Apple stayed with Lightning this long — and if not for the EU regulation would stay with it for years to come — because they're rolling in revenue from MFi licensing fees .

To the first part of that — that Apple only switched because the EU forced their hand — I say Well, maybe . It's obviously a factor. The EU is too big a market for Apple to walk away from. But the USB-C mandate doesn't kick in until next year, and existing devices from 2023 and earlier will still be allowed when the regulation does kick in. So the iPhones 15 could have had Lightning ports and remained available in the EU for years to come. It's next year when Apple would have to switch.

And if Apple really wanted to stick with Lightning, they could, in theory, make USB-C iPhones only for the EU market, and limit them all to the same USB 2 transfer speeds as Lightning. That would make for a supply chain hassle, to be sure, but it seems like less of a hassle than making iPhones with two SIM card trays just for the Hong Kong and Chinese markets .

As for the second part of the consensus thinking on why Apple has stuck with Lightning — that it's an MFi licensing money grab — I say Hogwash . Multiple sources have confirmed for me that MFi licensing revenue for Lightning devices and cables is negligible, just a rounding error by Apple's standards. But consider the arrogance of thinking that Apple would spitefully hold the iPhone back just for a bit of licensing revenue. That Apple would knowingly make the iPhone worse for no benefit other than their own financial bottom line. That's bonkers. I think the opposite is true: Apple pulls no punches when it comes to making the iPhone as good as it can possibly be for the most customers, even to the detriment of Apple's other devices. For one thing, it would make more sense for bleeding edge Apple silicon to be designed first for the Mac, and to trickle down to the iPhone in subsequent years. But instead, Apple silicon is designed for and ships first for the iPhone, and then flows up to the Mac and iPad. The iPhone gets Apple's best silicon (now on a 3nm process, the first in the world for any consumer product), best displays, and best materials (now titanium). It is the best device Apple can possibly make given the constraints of reasonable pricing and the inordinate scale at which it needs to produce them. No effort is spared — year after year after year. And nothing, not even a global year-plus-long pandemic, could knock it off its annual schedule. Apple loves all its products, but it loves the iPhone most.

And but we're supposed to believe that Apple deliberately made the iPhone's charging and data port worse , for years, for a fistful or two of dollars? My god, the sheer arrogance it takes to believe that Apple takes for granted an iota of the iPhone's success and enduring popularity.

The simple fact is that Apple kept all iPhones on Lightning while it thought staying on Lightning was the best choice for the most customers. I know that there have been engineers inside Apple — engineers who helped invent both Lightning and USB-C — who've been advocating for the iPhone to switch from Lightning ever since USB-C debuted in MacBooks in 2015. Maybe Apple should have switched sooner. But there were good reasons not to, mostly surrounding the trust involved in building an ecosystem. When they switched from the 30-pin connector to Lightning, Phil Schiller said it would be the connector for “the next decade”. That was the iPhone 5 in 2012.

In actual use, I have to say it is a little weird having USB-C on the iPhone. I got curious and connected an iPhone 15 Pro to my iPad Pro to see what would happen. The first time, the iPhone started charging the iPad. That wasn't what I expected, and from what I gather, isn't supposed to happen. I unplugged the cable and tried again, and the same thing happened: the iPhone charged the iPad. I unplugged the cable and swapped one side of the cable for the other, and this time the iPad started charging the iPhone, as though the cable had a direction for charging. Craziness. I tried again and the iPad (a 2018 11-inch iPad Pro running iPadOS 17) crashed. I expect Apple will straighten this out, but I'm surprised it's buggy at the moment.

Overall, though, it just isn't that big a deal. It's nice to know that 10 Gbps USB 3 transfer speeds are available for the iPhones 15 Pro — 20 times faster than the USB 2 limit of 480 Mbps (which remains the cap on the non-pro iPhone 15 models). But it's irritating, as with all things related to “USB-C” cables, that you'll need special (and more expensive) cables to achieve those transfer speeds, and there's no way to identify which cables support which transfer speeds just by looking at them, unless they have the Thunderbolt logo on the connector — but expensive, thick Thunderbolt cables are overkill for USB 3 data transfer. The cables that ship with all iPhone 15 models are nice, white 2 braided cables, but are not high-speed USB 3 cables. ( These cables from Monoprice are good options .)

The reason Apple opposed (and continues to oppose, even as their product line falls into compliance) the EU's USB-C port mandate isn't because they wanted to stick with Lightning forever. Why did they start migrating the iPad lineup from Lightning to USB-C back in 2018 if they were all-in on Lightning forever? The big problem isn't that they're required to ship USB-C ports in all products next year — it's that they'll be required to continue shipping USB-C ports in perpetuity until the regulation is revised or rescinded, and regulations like this tend never to be revised nor rescinded. If you think USB-C is a “forever port” that will never be bettered by a superior design, you've got nothing to worry about. But Apple doesn't think that way. Someday there will be a port that's better than USB-C, and that ’s when this EU regulation is going to pose a problem, because that future port is almost certain to be a proprietary one, not an open standard from the USB consortium, among whose members there exists but one company that I know of that had the good taste never to ship a single product using the gross Micro-USB or Mini-USB ports. Which of those companies is pushing for something better than USB-C?

There will be a successor to USB-C eventually. It'll probably be invented by Apple. The best we can hope for is that that successor will be inductive, or even over-the-air wireless, and thus not subject to the EU's plug mandate.

  1. There's a fourth major new camera feature this year for the 15 Pro models: shooting spatial video, ideal for consumption on the forthcoming Vision Pro. But shooting spatial video on the iPhone 15 Pro is “coming later this year”. Apple has not made available to reviewers pre-release software that enables it, nor was it available to demonstrate last week at the event in Cupertino. So not only have I not been able to try shooting it, I haven't even been able to see what a spatial video looks like when played back on an iPhone display. So, a mere footnote it is for this feature. ↩︎

  2. Amongst other botched details, the rumor mill shit the bed on the color-matched cable thing this year. ↩︎︎

entry.summary: At this point AirPods Pro 2 are as much better than the original AirPods Pro than the original AirPods Pro were from just-plain AirPods. They're far more than wireless earbuds — they're clever, powerful, delightful computers you put in your ears.
entry.content:
Among the oft-quoted Alan Kay's numerous aphorisms is “The best way to predict the future is to invent it.” A sort-of corollary to that, which I believe, is that the best way to appreciate new technology is to go back to using an older version.

A few weeks ago I was running late for an appointment I'd be walking to here in Philadelphia. Most everywhere I walk, I wear my AirPods Pro 2, but that day I couldn't find them, and I was late enough that I didn't have time to search. I was terribly worried I'd be alone with my own thoughts for the entire journey, but my old first-generation AirPods Pro were sitting on my desk, and they still had a charge, so I wore those instead.

I remember thinking last year , when I first upgraded from the original AirPods Pro to the AirPods Pro 2, that the new ones sounded at least a little better and that both Transparency and Active Noise Cancellation modes were much improved. But going back to the original AirPods Pro for just one afternoon walking around the city really brought home just how much improved the AirPods Pro 2 are. Transparency mode and Noise Cancellation are way better, and more strikingly, just the audio quality difference alone was obvious. After a year as a near-daily user of AirPods Pro 2, I now find the audio quality of the first-generation ones to be thin and tinny. I was downright blown away by the difference.

Last week Apple announced a minor revision to the AirPods Pro 2. They now come with a USB-C charging port on the case (instead of Lightning), and some sort of upgrade to the H2 chip in the earbuds of the revised models will enable low-latency lossless audio with the Vision Pro headset when that product ships next year.

I've been wearing a pair of the revised AirPods Pro 2 earbuds since last week, paired with my year-old iPhone 14 Pro and a few other devices. I obviously can't say anything about their special capabilities when paired with a Vision Pro, but in all regards related to currently-shipping features, they're better than ever.

As of today a firmware update is available for all AirPods models. For the second-generation AirPods Pro — both the year-old ones with Lightning and the new ones with USB-C — this is a major feature update. Tweaked features include the option to mute/unmute yourself with a click of an earbud stem while using AirPods during a phone or VoIP call, and improvements to both Transparency and Active Noise Cancellation modes. But the update also brings two new features.

The first new feature is Conversation Awareness, which Apple describes thus :

When you're wearing AirPods Pro and need to speak with someone nearby, Conversation Awareness automatically lowers the volume of what's playing, enhances voices in front of you, and reduces background noise.

When enabled (all AirPods options are set in the Settings app on iOS or MacOS), Conversation Awareness really is completely automatic. If you're listening to music or a podcast and just start talking to someone, or if someone else just starts talking to you, it kicks in. It's very clever, but whether you'll enjoy it highly depends upon your listening environment. In my 5+ days of testing, it kicked in too frequently amidst a crowd of people, none of whom were talking to me. Sometimes on city sidewalks, oftentimes in a grocery store. In an urban environment, there are just too many people talking around me, and the AirPods have no way of knowing that they're not talking to me, for this feature to be anything but an annoyance overall. But it's definitely accurate: it always kicks in when I start talking, and every time it has kicked in when someone else was talking near me, even when they weren't talking to me, I could tell whose voice it was that the AirPods detected. File this feature under “Not for me personally, but you might love it.”

The second new feature is a new listening mode: Adaptive Audio. One way to think of Adaptive Audio is as a mid-point between Transparency and Active Noise Cancellation (ANC). That's how Apple describes it:

The H2-powered AirPods Pro now feature Adaptive Audio, automatically prioritizing sounds that need your attention as you move through the world. By seamlessly blending Active Noise Cancellation with Transparency mode when you need it, Adaptive Audio magically delivers the right mix of sound for any environment.

Feel free to roll your eyes (or ears) at technology being described as “magical”, but damned if I can come up with a more apt adjective. In my (admittedly brief) testing time, Adaptive Audio seems more like a next-generation, even smarter replacement for Transparency mode. I've set mine to toggle between just two modes when I long-press either AirPod stem: Adaptive and ANC. If you'd like, you can add regular Transparency as a third mode you toggle between, but I haven't yet found an environment where I'd want plain Transparency instead of Adaptive. Transparency with AirPods Pro 2 has been great as an urban pedestrian; Adaptive is even better. It just automatically Does What I Want™ in seemingly every context. I hear traffic and passersby, but even loud trucks and buses passing by don't keep me from clearly hearing the podcast (typically) or song (less typically) I'm listening to.

Perhaps my usage scenarios are in the sweet spot for what Adaptive Audio is good at — the opposite of how my usage scenarios are not good for Conversation Awareness. But from my time using them, I don't even see why Adaptive Audio isn't a replacement for Transparency. For me, so far, it's just Transparency but better, with more on-the-fly dynamic adjustments. It's fantastic. (Perhaps battery life is one reason to keep plain Transparency mode around, but I have zero complaints about the battery life I've gotten these past five days.)

If you already use AirPods Pro, you know there are cute sounds that play when you switch modes. Each mode gets its own unique tone, and the tones for Transparency and Active Noise Cancellation sort of sound like the opposite of each other. The tones suggest “opening” and “closing” the world around you as you toggle them. Adaptive Audio has a new tone, which I'd describe as spritely or joyful. It's the sort of sound you can imagine a fairy's magic wand making in a kid's movie. It's a fun sound for a fun mode, and I can't help but take the joyfulness of this tone as a subtle suggestion from Apple that this is the “best” mode for most people in most scenarios, other than the obvious situations where you want full-on immersive Active Noise Cancellation.

The Vision Pro is Apple's initial foray into spatial computing. But Vision Pro is not Apple's first product in the world of augmented reality: AirPods Pro (and to a lesser degree, at the moment, AirPods Max) are. We humans are visual creatures and we naturally tend to think of augmented reality as a primarily visual experience, but AirPods Pro offer profoundly enjoyable and useful augmentation of the aural world around you. Starting today, Adaptive Audio takes that to another level.

Adaptive Audio is only available for the AirPods Pro 2, which means I'm only going to be more irritated if I ever again find myself wearing my old first-generation AirPods Pro out of necessity. At this point AirPods Pro 2 are as much better than the original AirPods Pro than the original AirPods Pro seemed from the original non-pro AirPods. They're far more than wireless earbuds — they're clever, powerful, delightful computers you put in your ears. I'll close with what I wrote about them a year ago :

The new AirPods Pro are the best single expression of Apple as a company today. Not the most important product, not the most complicated, not the most essential. But the one that exemplifies everything Apple is trying to do. They are simple, they are useful, and they offer features that most people use and want. Most people use headphones. A lot of people use them every day — in noisy environments. AirPods Pro are — for any scenario where big over-ear-style headphones are impractical — the best headphones in the world.
